title: How to Store Chocolate‐Covered Strawberries

steps.headline: Line a container with a paper towel and baking soda.
steps.description: Sprinkle a very light layer of baking soda on a paper towel. Place the paper towel on the bottom of an airtight plastic container. The baking soda will absorb excess moisture within the container and keep the strawberries from getting soggy. Use a container that is large enough to accommodate all of the strawberries. Use more than one paper towel if necessary.

steps.headline: Place a plate inside the container.
steps.description: Find a plate that will fit inside the container and will accommodate all of your chocolate-covered strawberries. Place the plate on top of the paper towel. The plate will keep the strawberries from touching the baking soda at the bottom of the container. If you can't fit a plate in your container, put down a thick layer of waxed paper to place your chocolate-covered strawberries on. Alternatively, place your chocolate-covered strawberries in a large ice cube tray and place it in the container.

steps.headline: Put your chocolate-covered strawberries in the plastic container.
steps.description: Place the chocolate-covered strawberries on the plate inside the container. Make sure that they are laid out in a single layer. Arrange them so that they are not touching each other, if possible.

steps.headline: Seal the container tightly.
steps.description: Put the lid on your plastic container and press down firmly to close it. You should always store your chocolate-covered strawberries in an airtight plastic container. These treats have a short shelf life, so a tightly sealed container is the best bet to seal out humidity and keep them fresh.

steps.headline: Keep them in a cool place right before serving them.
steps.description: If you plan to serve or eat your chocolate-covered strawberries within a few hours, avoid putting them in the fridge. Instead, put them in a plastic container and leave them in a cool, dry place (e.g., a kitchen pantry). Make sure to keep them away from any heat sources, which could melt the chocolate.

steps.headline: Transport chocolate covered strawberries with a freezer pack.
steps.description: To prevent your strawberries from melting during transport, place a freezer pack inside or underneath the container they are packed in. Put the freezer pack in a ziplock bag or wrap it in newspaper. This will act as a barrier for the condensation when it begins to unfreeze.

steps.headline: Place the strawberries in the fridge to keep them for one to three days.
steps.description: If you want to keep chocolate-covered strawberries for longer than a day, seal them in a plastic container and store them in the fridge. They may keep for up to three days, but the taste and texture will diminish in quality over time. Chocolate-covered strawberries have a tendency to release their natural juices when they’re refrigerated, which diminishes their flavor. Space out your strawberries as much as possible so that they don’t stick together. Remove the strawberries from the fridge about half an hour before you plan to serve them so that they can warm to room temperature.

steps.headline: Store the strawberries in the freezer for up to three months.
steps.description: If you don't eat your chocolate-covered strawberries right away, freeze them to preserve them for longer. Place them in a freezer-safe container and seal it tightly. Keep the strawberries for up to three months. Always defrost chocolate-covered strawberries in the refrigerator for approximately 24 hours before serving them. If they go directly from the freezer to room temperature, condensation will occur and make them soggy.

steps.headline: Check for signs of spoiled strawberries.
steps.description: Always look at your chocolate covered strawberries carefully before eating them, especially after they've been stored. Throw away the strawberries if they are mushy, discolored, bruised, or moldy. Spoiled chocolate covered strawberries can cause illness so you should get rid of them as soon as you see any of these signs. To keep homemade chocolate covered strawberries from going bad early, use the freshest strawberries possible. For the best results, buy strawberries with packaging that lists "packaged on" or "best by" dates.
